Title: Anamorphic Chaetosphaeriaceous Fungi from China
Abstract:
Chaetosphaeriaceae is one of the largest family of
Sordariomycetes that commonly found on plant litters in nature. This
paper reports our research result of diversity, taxonomy and phylogeny
of anamorphic Chaetosphaeriaceae in China, which is based on a
systematic study by using the integrated approach of morphological
observation and phylogenetic analysis for a large collection (>1500
herbarium specimens and 1200 living strains). The family
Chaetosphaeriaceae is further expanded to accomendate 91 accepted
genera, including 24 new genera and 10 newly assigned genera. Most of
these genera (except for Chaetosphaeria and several other relatively
large genera) are delimitated as monophyletic genera with well-defined
diagnostic morphological characters. The phylogenetic connection of
non-phialidic Sporidesmium-like fungi with the family is further
confirmed and expanded to 10 different genera. The polyphyletic
Codinaea/Dictyochaeta complex is partly resolved with a taxonomic
framework of 27 monophyletic genera by redelimitation of Codinaea and
Dictyochaeta in narrow concept, acceptance of 11 established genera, and
finally introduction of 14 several new genera. Chloridium is
phylogenetically redefined as monophyletic genus with narrow concept as
typified by the type species, a systematic review in both generic and
species level is still needed for the genus. Revision is also made for
several published Chaetosphaeria species. For biodiversity of
chaetosphaeriaceous fungi, a total of 372 species in 77 genera,
including 129 new species, 56 new combinations, and 1 new name, are
fully documented in this paper and the identification keys are provided
for most genera. One of the future research area for this family should
be systematic revision of several relatively large polyphyletic genera,
including Ellisembia, Stanjehughesia, Cacumisporium, Chaetosphaeria,
Chloridium, Craspedodidymum, Cryptophiale, Cryptophialoidea,
Dictyochaetopsis, Minimidochium, and many published species of Codinaea
and Dictyochaeta
